sect1.title: {foreach},{foreachelse}
sect1.para: {foreach} is used to loop over an associative array as well a numerically-indexed array, unlike {section} which is for looping over numerically-indexed arrays only. The syntax for {foreach} is much easier than {section}, but as a tradeoff it can only be used for a single array. Every {foreach} tag must be paired with a closing {/foreach} tag.
Smarty3 introduced also an alternative new syntax for the {foreach} tags. See {foreach} - new style.

row.entry: The array you are looping through
The name of the variable that is the current element
The name of the variable that is the current key
The name of the foreach loop for accessing foreach properties

listitem.para: Required attributes are from and item.

note.title: Note
note.para: The variable specified by the item attribute must have a different name as the variable specified bay the from attribute.

listitem.para: The name of the {foreach} loop can be anything you like, made up of letters, numbers and underscores, like PHP variables.
{foreach} loops can be nested, and the nested {foreach} names must be unique from each other.
The from attribute, usually an array of values, determines the number of times {foreach} will loop.
{foreachelse} is executed when there are no values in the from variable.

{foreach} loops also have their own variables that handle properties. These are accessed with:
{$smarty.foreach.name.property} with name being the name attribute.

note.title: Note
note.para: The name attribute is only required when you want to access a {foreach} property, unlike {section}. Accessing a {foreach} property with name undefined does not throw an error, but leads to unpredictable results instead.

listitem.para: {foreach} properties are index, iteration, first, last, show, total.

Smarty3 does introduce a new alternative way to access {foreach} properties. The properties are also attached to the item variable. The syntax is {$item@property} (see examples below). If you use this syntax to access the properties it's no longer required to name the {foreach} loop with the item attribute.
Instead of specifying the key attribute you can access the current key of the loop item by {$item@key} (see examples below).

example.title: The item attribute
example.programlisting:
<?php
$arr = array(1000, 1001, 1002);
$smarty->assign('myArray', $arr);
?>
example.para: Template to output $myArray in an un-ordered list
example.programlisting:
{foreach from=$myArray item=foo}
  • {$foo}
    • {/foreach}

example.title: Demonstrates the item and key attributes
example.programlisting:
<?php
$arr = array(9 => 'Tennis', 3 => 'Swimming', 8 => 'Coding');
$smarty->assign('myArray', $arr);
?>
example.para: Template to output $myArray as key/val pair, like PHP's foreach.
example.programlisting:
{foreach from=$myArray key=k item=v}
  • {$k}: {$v}
    • {/foreach}

example.title: {foreach} with associative item attribute
example.programlisting:
<?php
$items_list = array(23 => array('no' => 2456, 'label' => 'Salad'),
                    96 => array('no' => 4889, 'label' => 'Cream')
                    );
$smarty->assign('items', $items_list);
?>
example.para: Template to output $items with $myId in the url
example.programlisting:
{foreach from=$items key=myId item=i}
  • {$i.no}: {$i.label}
    • {/foreach}

example.title: {foreach} with nested item and key
example.para: Assign an array to Smarty, the key contains the key for each looped value.
example.programlisting: <?php $smarty->assign('contacts', array( array('phone' => '1', 'fax' => '2', 'cell' => '3'), array('phone' => '555-4444', 'fax' => '555-3333', 'cell' => '760-1234') )); ?>
example.screen:
phone: 1
fax: 2
cell: 3
phone: 555-4444
fax: 555-3333
cell: 760-1234

example.title: Database example with {foreachelse}
example.para: A database (eg PEAR or ADODB) example of a search script, the query results assigned to Smarty
example.programlisting:
<?php
  $search_condition = "where name like '$foo%' ";
  $sql = 'select contact_id, name, nick from contacts '.$search_condition.' order by name';
  $smarty->assign('results', $db->getAssoc($sql) );
?>
example.para: The template which display None found if no results with {foreachelse}.

sect2.title: .index
sect2.para: index contains the current array index, starting with zero.

example.title: index example
example.para: Same as above but property index attached to item variable.

sect2.title: .iteration
sect2.para: iteration contains the current loop iteration and always starts at one, unlike index. It is incremented by one on each iteration.

example.title: iteration and index example
example.para: Same as above but property iteration and indexindex attached to item variable.

sect2.title: .first
sect2.para: first is &true; if the current {foreach} iteration is the initial one.

example.title: first property example
example.para: Same as above but key and property first attached to item variable.

sect2.title: .last
sect2.para: last is set to &true; if the current {foreach} iteration is the final one.

example.title: last property example
example.para: Same as above but property last attached to item variable.

sect2.title: .show
sect2.para: The show show property can be used after the excution of the {foreach} to detect if data has been display or not. show is a boolean value.
sect2.programlisting:
{foreach from=$myArray item=foo name=bar}
  • {$foo}
    • {/foreach}
{if $smarty.foreach.bar.show} do something if the array did contain data {/if}
sect2.para: Same as above but property show attached to item variable.

example.title: show property example
example.programlisting:
{foreach from=$myArray item=foo name=bar}
  • {$foo}
    • {/foreach}
{if $foo@show} do something if the array did contain data {/if}

sect2.title: .total
sect2.para: total contains the number of iterations that this {foreach} will loop. This can be used inside or after the {foreach}.

example.title: total property example
example.para: Same as above but property last and total attached to item variable.
